questions.solution:
Basic classification of contrast media used in radiology

Iodine

  1. Most of the i.v. contrast media contain iodine which has an atomic number 53 and atomic weight 127.
  2. Total iodine content in the body is 50 mg.
  3. It's preferred because
    • High contrast density due to high atomic number
    • Allows firm binding to highly variable benzene ring
    • Low toxicity.
  4. It's not suitable for MRI.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A: Barium - Water insoluble agent, used for the Barium procedures like Barium swallow, Barium meal, Barium meal follow through, Barium enema, etc.

Choice C: Bromium : Not use as an contrast agent.

Choice D: Calcium : Not use as contrast agent.

Key takeaway:

  • Examples of negative contrast media.
  • Examples of positive contrast media.
  • Properties of iodine as a contrast agent.

A gasless abdomen refers to a paucity of gas on abdominal radiography and the specific cause can usually be identified when the patient's history is known.

Common causes include:

  • proximal obstruction: gastric outlet obstructions, Oesophageal atria.
  • Small bowel ischemia.
  • Ascites.
  • Acute pancreatitis.
  • Gastroenteritis.
  • Larfge abdominal mass - due to displacement
  • Post surgery following pancolectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy and lowe anterior resection.
  • acute gastrointestinal graft vs host reaction
  • a paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice B: Usually presented as the findings of small bowel obstruction with multiple air fluid levels.

Choice C: Necrotising enterocolitis: in severe cases there is gas within the bowel wall and portal veins, pneumoperitoneum can also seen.

Choice D: Ulcerative colitis: usually there is no x-ray features in the ulcerative colitis.

Reference: Mudgal P, Bell D, Niknejad M, et al. Gasless abdomen. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-2692

questions.text: Boot shaped heart in tetralogy of fallot is due to?
questions.solution:
Image description:

Frontal chest radiograph of pediatric patient with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) shows characteristic boot-shaped heart with hyperlucent lungs, diminished central hilar pulmonary vessels, and an upturned cardiac apex. Main pulmonary artery segment is flat to concave, and the right aortic arch is seen.

The boot-shaped heart sign is a conventional radiographic finding in patients with TOF. The toe of the boot is formed by the upward pointing cardiac apex, which makes an acute angle with the diaphragm. The upturned cardiac apex is ascribed to right ventricular hypertrophy and occurs in 65% of patients with TOF.

The narrower upper part of the boot results from a small or absent main pulmonary artery partly caused by a narrow infundibulum and hypoplastic main pulmonary artery. The latter has been confirmed at angiocardiography in 57% of patients.

The sign is accentuated by a large lung volume, a small thymus, and the lordotic projection. When a normal thymus is present, the left lobe may obscure the sign.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
    • A VSD is a crucial part of TOF but does not directly cause the boot-shaped heart.
    • While a large VSD contributes to right-to-left shunting and cyanosis, it does not affect the cardiac silhouette.
  • Choice C: Overriding of Aorta
    • The overriding aorta is another key feature of TOF but is not responsible for the boot shape.
    • It contributes to systemic desaturation but does not influence the cardiac apex position.
  • Choice D: Pulmonary Stenosis
    • Pulmonary stenosis leads to RVH over time but does not directly cause the boot-shaped heart.
    • The small main pulmonary artery (due to stenosis) contributes to the narrowing of the upper part of the boot but not to the apical upturn.

Key takeaway:

  • The toe of the boot is formed by the upward pointing cardiac apex, which makes an acute angle with the diaphragm.
  • The narrower upper part of the boot results from a small or absent main pulmonary artery partly caused by a narrow infundibulum and hypoplastic main pulmonary artery.
  • The sign is accentuated by a large lung volume, a small thymus, and the lordotic projection.

References:

Haider, E. A. (2008). The boot-shaped heart sign. Radiology, 246(1), 328-329. https://doi.org/10.1148/radiol.2461041673

questions.text: Identify the investigation done?
questions.solution:
Image description:

Barium contrast is seen within the stomach, duodenum and small bowel loops.

For radiological evaluation of small bowel, both barium meal follow through and enteroclysis are superior to CT/MRI examination in terms of demonstration of fine mucosal detail Small bowel follow through study is easy to perform, allows estimation of transit time and is more comfortable to the patient. However, complete and adequate distension of the small bowel cannot be achieved in followthrough study.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A: Barium upper GI study: usually includes esophagus, stomach, duodenum and DJ junction.

Barium upper GI study shows well-distended stomach with normal mucosal pattern.

Choice B: Barium swallow: usually includes esophagus and gastro-esophageal junction.

The lower thoracic esophagus and gastroesophageal junction well seen in the distended state in a normal barium swallow.

Choice D: Barium enema: Special study for the large bowel i.e. colon and rectum and usuallu involves IC junction.

Double contrast barium enema. Supine radiograph showing normal mucosal outline of the cecum, ascending colon, part of transverse colon and descending colon. The hepatic flexure and rectosigmoid colon are in a dependent position and hence seen in a barium-filled state.

Key takeaway:

Identification of each procedure by the Images of each study is must for the competitive exams.

questions.text: Probable diagnosis of the given IVP image is?
questions.solution:
Image description:

There is focal terminal dilatation of bilateral ureters are seen. Also known as a "Cobra head appearance".

  • The term ureterocele means saccular dilatation of the intramural portion of ureter as it passes through the bladder wall.
  • It may be of two types-simple (orthotopic) and ectopic.
  • The ureters of a simple ureterocele drain a nonduplex kidney and insert into the bladder at their normal position at the trigone.
  • An ectopic ureterocele frequently occurs in a duplex kidney. In complete duplication, the ureter of the upper moiety generally inserts at a lower/ectopic location. This ureter is generally affected with ureterocele (the lower moiety, on the other hand is predisposed for VUR).
  • Morphologically, ureteroceles can be completely intravesical or extravesical-where the dilated portion extends outside the UB to involve the distal ureter.
  • Ureterocele typically appear on urography and cystography as smooth, rounded or ovoid filling defect in the bladder. The major concern with ureterocele is obstruction, stasis, and UTI. Hence, treatment is directed toward relieving the obstruction using cystoscopy, partial nephrectomy for the nonfunctioning upper moiety and/or ureteric reimplantation for refluxing ureter of lower moiety.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice B: Genitourinary TB in ureter shows Dilatation-due to atony and prolonged bacilluria

  • Long segment strictures-most commonly at distal one-third
  • Beaded/corkscrew ureter
  • "Pipe stem ureter"-rigid shortened ureter with narrow lumen
  • Ureteral calcifications (uncommon)

Choice C: VUR: diffuse dilatation of ureters seen. usually seen on MCU study, dilated ureters with associated renal pelvis dilatation of varying grades.

Choice D: Ureteric calculus seen as a filling defect on the IVP study with or without proximal dilatation of the ureter.

Key takeaway:

  • The term ureterocele means saccular dilatation of the intramural portion of ureter as it passes through the bladder wall.
  • "Cobra head appearance"

questions.text: Chest x ray of a patient with low grade fever is given below, probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image description:

  • The given x ray chest PA view suggest the miliary pattern of involvement. Miliary nodules means innumerable small nodules in bilateral lung fields measuring approx 1-3 mm in diameter.
  • Causes:
    1. TB
    2. Viral
    3. Fungal infection
    4. pulmonary metastasis

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice B: ILD: usually shows diffuse reticulonodular type of opacities involving both lung fields with typical gradient of involvement according to the type.

Choice C: Broncho-pneumonia: Usually seen as the lobar type of involvement informing consolidation and air bronchogram.

Choice D: Consolidation: usually seen as ill-defined radio-opacity with internal air bronchogram, with or without peripheral GGO.

Key takeaway:

  • Miliary nodules means innumerable small nodules in bilateral lung fields measuring approx 1-3 mm in diameter.
  • Causes:
    1. TB
    2. Viral
    3. Fungal infection
    4. pulmonary metastasis

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen on barium swallow in a case of mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Mitral stenosis leads to left atrial enlargement, which causes external compression on the mid esophagus. Left atrium is the closest part of heart which remains in touch with the mid esophagus.

The oesophagus is displaced posteriorly and to the left side with mid oesophagal narrowing that doesn't persist all through the study suggesting external compression. The shadow of the enlarged left atrium is noted on oblique views. Also a large amount of contrast reflux at the Trendelenburg position is noted.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice B, C, D: These chambers are not in direct contact with the esophagus.

Key takeaway:

Extrinsic compression, e.g.

  • multinodular goiter
  • Aberrant right subclavian artery
  • anterior osteophytes from cervical spine disease
  • hypertrophic cartilages e.g. superior thyroid cornu syndrome
  • occasionally as a complication of anterior cervical spine fusion (~4%)
  • retropharyngeal abscess

Reference:

Abdrabou A, Left atrial enlargement. Case study, Radiopaedia.org https://doi.org/10.53347/rID-23098

Image refernce: https://advance.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.22541/au.170670385.55607657/v1

questions.text: Nuchal translucency scan is done at?
questions.solution:
Definition: Nuchal Translucency (NT) is the sonographic appearance of subcutaneous accumulation of fluid behind the foetal neck in the first trimester of pregnancy.

The term translucency is used, irrespective of whether it is septated or not, and whether it is confined to the neck or envelops the whole foetus. The incidence of abnormalities is related to the size, rather than morphological appearance of NT.

NT usually resolves in the second trimester and, in a few cases, it either evolves into nuchal oedema or cystic hygroma with/without generalised hydrops.

Optimal gestational age for measurement of NT:

The optimal gestational age for measurement of foetal NT is 11 weeks to 13 weeks and 6 days.

The minimum foetal CRL should be 45 mm and the maximum 84 mm (hence, this is sometimes referred to as 4584 scan).

Why is 11 weeks selected as the earliest period of this study?

  1. Screening necessitates the availability of a diagnostic test for confirmation (in this case being chorionic villous sampling). CVS done before this gestation is associated with transverse limb reduction defects.
  2. Many major structural abnormalities may sometimes be missed before this period.

For example, a diagnosis of acrania/anencephaly cannot be done before 11 weeks as the sonographic appearance of foetal skull ossification is unreliable before 11 weeks. Similarly, at 8-10 weeks, during the period of physiological midgut herniation, a diagnosis of exomphalos may not be made. Also, the foetal bladder can be visualised in only 50% of foetuses at 10 weeks, but in 80% and 100% of cases at 11 weeks and 12 weeks respectively.

Why is 13+6 weeks selected as the upper limit of this study?

  1. To provide an option for early termination if necessary.
  2. Incidence of abnormal NT in chromosomally abnormal foetuses is lower after 14 weeks.
  3. Sometimes a more vertical orientation of foetus may make it difficult to obtain an appropriate image for measurement of NT (thereby reducing the success rate of NT measurement after 14 weeks).

Ideal image for measurement of NT

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: 8-10 weeks
    • Too early for NT measurement.
    • The fetal crown-rump length (CRL) is too small, and key structures are not yet well-developed.
    • Diagnosis of anomalies like exomphalos or acrania is unreliable.
  • Choice C: 14-18 weeks
    • Beyond the optimal window for NT assessment.
    • By this time, NT usually resolves or evolves into nuchal edema/cystic hygroma.
    • Other second-trimester markers (e.g., quadruple screen, anatomy scan) are preferred.
  • Choice D: 18-20 weeks
    • Far too late for NT measurement.
    • Structural anomalies are now evaluated using a detailed anomaly scan, not NT.

Key takeaway:

  • Nuchal Translucency (NT) is the sonographic appearance of subcutaneous accumulation of fluid behind the foetal neck in the first trimester of pregnancy.
  • The optimal gestational age for measurement of foetal NT is 11 weeks to 13 weeks and 6 days.

Reference:

ICRI Guidelines On First Trimester Anomaly Scan/Aneuploidy Risk Assessment/Pre-Eclampsia Screening (11 - 13+6 Weeks Obstetric Scan), July 2020.

questions.text: A 65 year old lady with backache and a lateral radiograph of the spine is shown, most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Spondylolisthesis denotes the slippage of one vertebra relative to the one below.

Although it is directionless and could be applied to both anterolisthesis and retrolisthesis, in practice, spondylolisthesis is used synonymously with anterolisthesis. Often, particularly in the lower lumbar spine, it is due to spondylolysis (pars interarticularis defects).

Classification

To determine the grade of spondylolisthesis using the Meyerding classification, two vertical lines are drawn along the posterior cortex superior and inferior vertebra, and a measurement is taken between them (A). The length of the inferior vertebral body is also measured (B). A calculation of A/B determines the grade 4:

  • grade I: 0-25%
  • grade II: 26-50%
  • grade III: 51-75%
  • grade IV: 76-100%
  • grade V (spondyloptosis): >100%

The grades can be further grouped as 4:

  • "low-grade": grades 1 and 2
  • "high-grade": grades 3, 4 and 5

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Osteoporosis: Generalized decrease in the bone density of all bones mainly due to old age.

Choice B: Spondylolysis, commonly known as pars interarticularis defect or pars defect, is a defect in the pars interarticularis, the portion of the vertebral arch that connects the superior and inferior articular facets. It usually occurs in the lumbar spine.

Choice D: Discitis: inflammation of IV disc.

Key takeaway:

Difference between spondylolisthesis (Slippage of one vertebral body over other) and spondylolysis (pars interarticularis defects)

Reference:

Gaillard F, Walizai T, Knipe H, et al. Spondylolisthesis. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the image
questions.solution:
Image description:

T1wI mid-Sagittal image of brain. With cerebellum marked with red arrow.

Midline sagittal image of brain showing embryonal divisions.

Mid-sagittal MR section shows the entire length of the corpus callosum bordered above by the pericallosal sulcus. Cingulate gyrus and sulcus lie above it. The brainstem divisions, cerebellar vermis and the sellar/suprasellar anatomy are exquisitely shown on this section. The vein of Galen and straight sinus are seen behind the splenium leading to the torcula. A large rounded mass of gray matter within the 3rd ventricle represents interthalamic adhesion. The fornix is seen beneath the corpus callosum. The 3rd and 4th ventricles with the interconnecting aqueduct are well shown in this section. The tectal plate lies posterior to the aqueduct. The suprasellar cistern interpeduncular fossa, quadrigeminal plate cistern and cisterna magna are important cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) spaces identified in this section.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Cerebrum
    • The cerebrum comprises the largest part of the brain, including the frontal, parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes.
    • It is located above the cerebellum and is responsible for higher cognitive functions such as thinking, memory, and voluntary movements.
    • The marked structure does not correspond to the cerebrum.
  • Choice C: Brainstem
    • The brainstem consists of the midbrain, pons, and medulla and connects the cerebrum and spinal cord.
    • It is anterior to the cerebellum in a midsagittal section.
    • The marked structure is not the brainstem.
  • Choice D: Corpus Callosum
    • The corpus callosum is the largest white matter tract connecting the two cerebral hemispheres.
    • It is located superior to the cerebellum and brainstem, forming a C-shaped structure in the mid-sagittal view.
    • The marked structure does not correspond to the corpus callosum.

Key takeaway:

This is the must know section of the radiological anatomy of brain.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure given in the image?
questions.solution:
A, Axial T2-weighted image shows the postcommissural fibers of the fornix (yellow arrows) coursing posterior to the anterior commissure (green arrow). B, Coronal T2-weighted image shows the superoinferior orientation of the columns of the fornix (yellow arrows).

Schematic overview of the fornix from the side. The fimbria forms the crus of the fornix, which is joined to the opposite fornix across the midline by the commissure of the fornix (hippocampal commissure, psalterium). The body of the fornix (B) at the top of the fornical arch is connected to the inferior surface of the body of the corpus callosum by the septum pellucidum. The column of the fornix (C) has a more superoinferior orientation and is connected to the posterior margin of the genu of the corpus callosum by the septum pellucidum. The columns of the fornix are split at the level of the anterior commissure with most the fibers (postcommissural fibers) projecting to the mammillary bodies

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Pineal Gland
    • The pineal gland is a small, midline endocrine gland located posterior to the third ventricle, near the superior colliculus.
    • It is not associated with the fornix fibers or anterior commissure, making this choice incorrect.
  • Choice C: Pituitary
    • The pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, within the sella turcica.
    • It is anterior and inferior to the fornix and does not share its distinctive fiber tract appearance.
  • Choice D: Third Ventricle
    • The third ventricle is a CSF-filled space located between the two halves of the diencephalon.
    • While it is anatomically close to the fornix, it is not a fiber tract and would appear differently on MRI.

Key takeaway:

MRI brain anatomy in axial section is must know topic.

Reference:

Raslau, Flavius & Augustinack, Jean & Klein, Andrew & Ulmer, J & Mathews, V & Mark, L. (2015). Memory Part 3: The Role of the Fornix and Clinical Cases. AJNR. American journal of neuroradiology. 36. 10.3174/ajnr.A4371.

questions.text: A DWI MRI image of a 67 year old hypertensive and diabetic male presenting with left sided hemiplegia, diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Image description:

DWI (diffusion weighted imaging) MR image shows area of restricted diffusion in right MCA territory.

Magnetic resonance imaging is more sensitive for detecting acute infarct as compared to CT. During the initial few hours of ischemia, the findings on MRI are related to vascular occlusion and cytotoxic edema. The sensitivity of apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) maps and diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) are very sensitive for the diagnosis of acute stroke. An acute infarct is hypointense on ADC and hyperintense on DWI.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A : hypertensive bleed: does not show this much amount of homogeneous restriction on the diffusion. And shows foci of blooming on GRE images.

Choice C: SAH: Cresent shape radio-opacity is noted, crossing the suture line, causing mass effect on the underlying brain parenchyma.

Choice D: lacunar infarct: Lacunar infarcts (LACI) are small (<15 mm) infarcts in the distal distribution of deep penetrating vessels.

Key takeaway:

  • Magnetic resonance imaging is more sensitive for detecting acute infarct as compared to CT.
  • During the initial few hours of ischemia, the findings on MRI are related to vascular occlusion and cytotoxic edema.
  • An acute infarct is hypointense on ADC and hyperintense on DWI.

questions.text: CT scan image shows
questions.solution:
Axial NCCT brain image at bilateral thalamic region, shows well defined hypodense area involving left thalamic region, p/o lacunar infarct likely.

Lacunar infarcts (LACI) are small (<15 mm) infarcts in the distal distribution of deep penetrating vessels (lenticulostriate, thalamo-perforating, and pontine perforating arteries, recurrent artery of Heubner). They result from occlusion of one of the small penetrating end arteries at the base of the brain and have traditionally been thought to occur due to fibrinoid degeneration.

Most lacunar infarcts are clinically silent, but repeated episodes are associated with vascular dementia. Symptomatic patients may present with lacunar stroke syndrome, one of five distinct syndromes.

CT Findings:

In the acute setting, lacunar infarcts appear as ill-defined hypodensities.

Chronic lesions appear as hypodense foci, similar density to CSF.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Normal: hypodensity in left thalamic region is not a normal finding.

Choice C: Basal ganglia bleed: Bleed on NCCT appears as a hyperdense area, with decreasing hyper-density according to the age of hemorrhage.

Choice D: intraventricular hemorrhage: Shows hyperdense area in dependent portion of the ventricles.

Key takeaway:

  • Lacunar infarcts (LACI) are small (<15 mm) infarcts in the distal distribution of deep penetrating vessels.
  • CT Findings:
    In the acute setting, lacunar infarcts appear as ill-defined hypodensities.
    Chronic lesions appear as hypodense foci, similar density to CSF.

Reference:

Jones J, Walizai T, Bell D, et al. Lacunar infarct. Reference article, Radiopaedia.org

choices.text: Tumour arises from epiphyseal to metaphyseal region
Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Incorrect statement regarding the condition given in the image is?
questions.solution:
Image description:

Radiograph of the knee shows an eccentric expansile subarticular lytic lesion in distal end of femur without sclerotic margin.

Giant cell tumor constitutes about 5% of all bone tumors and slightly less than 20% of all benign tumors. The tumor originates from undifferentiated cells of the supporting tissues of bone marrow. As opposed to other benign tumors, GCT has a female predilection and mostly occurs after the closure of epiphysis, with a peak in the third decade.

Giant cell tumors arise eccentrically in the metaphysis with tendency to approach the adjacent subarticular cortex as they enlarge. About 40-50% of lesions occur around the knee.

Involvement of distal radius is seen in 10-12% which otherwise is an uncommon site for bone tumors.

Other sites are sacrum, short tubular bones, and vertebral bodies. Classical radiographic picture is that of a well-defined eccentric lytic lesion which expands the bone and is usually not surrounded by a sclerotic rim. Cortical penetration with or without an associated soft tissue mass is seen in 33-50% of cases.

Treatment is usually done by the curettage and bone cementing. Chemotherapy is usually not indicated as it is a benign tumor.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

  • Choice A: Sharp distinct border (Correct Statement)
    • GCT typically presents as an eccentric, well-defined, lytic lesion.
    • It often lacks a sclerotic rim, giving it a sharp, distinct border.
  • Choice B: Tumor arises from epiphyseal to metaphyseal region (Correct Statement)
    • GCT arises in the metaphysis and extends into the epiphysis after the growth plate has closed.
    • This is a characteristic feature of the tumor.
  • Choice D: Eccentric location (Correct Statement)
    • GCT arises eccentrically in the metaphysis, meaning it does not appear in the central part of the bone.
    • It tends to grow towards the subarticular cortex.

Key takeaway:

  • GCT has a female predilection and mostly occurs after the closure of epiphysis, with a peak in the third decade.
  • Usually not surrounded by a sclerotic rim.
  • Giant cell tumors arise eccentrically in the metaphysis with tendency to approach the adjacent subarticular cortex as they enlarge.

questions.text: A patient comes to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and an erect radiograph is shown, what is the definitive treatment of the given condition?
questions.solution:
Image description:

There is presence of free gas under the right dome of diaphragm, s/o Pneumoperitoneum.

Normally there is no free air within the peritoneal cavity. The most common cause of a pneumoperitoneum is due to rupture of an abdominal viscus. Other causes are-postoperative status, patient on peritoneal dialysis, rupture of a cyst in pneumatosis intestinalis etc.

The treatment of choice for that condition is supportive treatment and laparotomy for the identification of the cause of the condition.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice C: Gastric lavage: treatment for the poison ingestion.

Choice D: chest tube insertion: Treatment of choice for pneumothorax.

questions.text: A case of allergic rhinitis, NCCT image of paranasal air sinuses shows an appearance known as?
questions.solution:
Image description:

Coronal CT image of PNS shows soft tissue density area within the left nasal cavity with central hyperdensity within, k/a Double density sign. Classical for Allergic fungal rhino-sinusitis.

Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis

It occurs as an allergic response to fungal elements in atopic patients. On CT, diffuse mucosal thickening involving multiple sinuses is present. Within the sinus there may be central hyperdense content and peripheral hypodensity.

Bony destruction is usually not seen. Calcification is also a common finding in fungal infections especially with aspergillosis. Central or fine punctate pattern of calcification is characteristic of fungal infection. Many patients may have polyps.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Honeycombing: Honeycombing represents the destruction of lung parenchyma with loss of architecture and well-defined adjacent cystic structures, typically clustered in the subpleural region. The traditional definition requires several layers of cysts, but in current practice, this threshold has been reduced to a single layer of cysts, provided other signs of fibrosis are present. The diameter and wall thickness of the cysts are variable but their presence is inevitably accompanied by the complete effacement of normal lung architecture and usually occurs with other signs of pulmonary fibrosis, including traction bronchiolectasis.

Choice C: Onion peel appearance: it is a type of aggressive periosteal reaction seen in malignant bone tumors i.e. Ewings sarcoma.

Choice D: Ground glass opacity. Ground-glass refers to an area of increased attenuation that does not completely obscure the underlying bronchial and vascular structures. Although historically first described on radiographs specifics of this term have been defined for CT and it should only be applied in the context of CT. The finding is nonspecific, as ground-glass can be caused by any abnormal process below the resolution of the CT scanner that does not completely displace alveolar air, for example, partial filling of alveoli by fluid or cellular material, an increase in capillary blood volume, histologic fibrosis, a lepidic pattern of adenocarcinoma, or a combination of the above.

Key takeaway:

Double density sign in PNS CT: Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis

questions.text: A known case of pancreatitis develops breathlessness, basal crepitations on day 4, CXR is shown, probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Image description:

Chest X Ray shows bilateral patchy diffuse air space opacities predominantly on both lower and mid zones. ET tube in position.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a diffuse alveolar damage resulting from variety of insults and requiring mechanical ventilation. The pathology is diffuse alveolar damage, increased capillary and alveolar permeability, leading to edema (interstitial and alveolar), followed by a phase of fibrosis. Three clinical phases are recognized-acute, subacute and chronic.

Acute (Exudative) Phase

This is seen in the initial 7 days following insult. The chest radiograph can be normal in the first 24 hours. Over the next 2-3 days-extensive, bilateral air space opacification/consolidation ("White lung") can develop. The consolidation can be patchy and multifocal. Radiographic criteria for diagnosis of ARDS include bilateral opacities (consistent with pulmonary edema), findings not explainable by pleural effusion, lung collapse or nodules. CT findings can appear by 12 hours. HRCT findings include GGO and consolidation having a diffuse or patchy distribution. Usually there is an apico-basal gradient, with more opacification of the lung bases.

Subacute (Proliferative) Phase

It is between one and two weeks, when there is conversion of alveolar exudates into cellular granulation tissue. Imaging in subacute phase shows an increasing consolidation in early phase, followed by appearance of interlobular septal thickening, "crazy paving pattern" and bronchiectasis and bronchiolectasis.

Chronic (Fibrotic) Phase

It is seen two weeks or more following injury. Diffuse parenchymal fibrosis and architectural distortion ensue. HRCT reveals fibrosis, bronchiectasis, bronchiolectasis with distortion of airways and volume loss with bullae formation. Morphological changes may persist in survivors even when imaged months after the acute episode.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Lung collapse: Consolidation with decrease lung volume, shift of mediastinum to the same side are some signs of lung collapse.

Choice B : Pleural Effusion: Blunting of both CP angle with concavity of radioopacity towards the upper side on erect CXR is a sign of pleural effusion.

Choice D: Aspiration pneumonia: It occurs in the gravity dependent portions of the lung, so in recumbent patient it involves the posterior segment of the upper lobes and the superior segment of the lower lobes whereas in an erect patient, aspiration is more likely to involve bilateral basal segments, middle lobe, and lingular lobe. On imaging, it is often seen as a bronchopneumonia or bronchiolitis pattern.

Aspirated material may sometimes be seen in the bronchial lumen. A lung abscess may also be seen in bacterial aspiration.

Key takeaway:

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is a diffuse alveolar damage resulting from variety of insults and requiring mechanical ventilation.
  • Three clinical phases are recognized-acute, subacute and chronic.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of diplopia and restricted eye movements. A clinical image and CT image is shown below. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Description of the image shown in the question:

Blow out fracture. Coronal CT image (bone window) shows fracture of the medial wall and floor of the right orbit. There was no extraocular muscle entrapment on the soft tissue window (not shown).

Infraorbital fracture, the so called blow out fracture occurs when direct blunt force is applied to the globe and orbit with disruption of the orbital wall.

The floor or medial walls are most often fractured with the orbital rim remaining intact.

In patients with optic nerve injury following trauma, thin sections of CT may delineate the injured nerve, apical bony fragments and adjacent hematoma for crucial preoperative assessment. MRI may be complementary to CT scanning in certain patients particularly with injuries involving the globe or optic nerve.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Le fort fracture: other facial bones( maxilla, pterygoid, etc) appears normal.

Choice B: Maxilla appears unremarkable.

Choice C: Zygomatic bone appears normal.

Key takeaway:

  • Blowout fracture of orbit occurs due to direct blow on the orbit with sudden increase in intraorbital pressure.
  • The floor or medial walls are most often fractured with the orbital rim remaining intact.
